document.docTitle: Marolia alicantina Konvička & Brustel 2021, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Description of Marolia alicantina sp. nov. (Coleoptera: Melandryidae) from Spain and new distribution records of Marolia species

( ALC ) Alcoy / (Chȇnaie) Font Roja [p] / (FR3W3) [= abbreviation of precise locality of window trap] [ 38°39’50.63”N 0°32’23”W , 1087 m a.s.l.] 19.IV.2016 [h, w]’. All locality labels are framed in black. All specimens were provided with an additional red printed label: ‘
Marolia
/
alicantina
sp. nov.
/
HOLOTYPE
[or
PARATYPE
respectively] [sex] / Ondřej Konvička & / Hervé Brustel des. 2020’.

Description of holotype .
Body length 5.1 mm , width 1.7 mm . Body brown, elongate.

Antennae 11-segmented, brown, 2.5 times longer than the pronotum length and with long yellowish setae. Last three antennal segments are slightly lighter than the others. All antennomeres longer than wide. Length ratio of antennomeres I–XI: 0.9: 0.6: 1.0: 1.0: 0.95: 0.9: 0.9: 0.85: 0.8: 0.8: 0.8.

Aedeagus elongate, apex pointed, length: 1.25 mm . Median lobe extends to 4/5 of aedeagus in the direction from the apex to the base ( Fig. 8 ). Fifth tergite rounded, obtuse apically; on apical third of the fifth tergite bearing setae.
Variability. Body ♁♁ (n=16) length: 4.5–6.5 mm , width: 1.6–2.2 mm . ♀♀ (n=9): length: 4.9– 6.9 mm , width: 1.8– 2.5 mm .

caption.paragraph:
FIGS 1–7: 1 – holotype male of
Marolia alicantina
sp. nov. ; 2 – paratype female of
Marolia alicantina
sp. nov. (length 5.9 mm); 3 – paratype male of
Marolia alicantina
sp. nov. (length 5.1 mm); 4 – male of
Marolia grandis Peyerimhoff, 1917
(length 7 mm); 5 – male of
Marolia variegata (Bosc, 1791)
(length 5.7 mm); 6 – male of
Marolia leseigneuri Nicolas, 1977
(length 5 mm); 7 – male of
Marolia purkynei Mařan, 1933
(length 6 mm); 1–7 – habitus in dorsal view. (Fig. 1 photo Aleš Sedláček; Figs. 2–7 photo Pierre Zagatti).

subSubSection.paragraph: Body coloration is variable: clypeus and labrum varies from yellow to brown; setae vary from yellow to brownish yellow; the head is brownish-black to black. The color of the pronotum varies from brown to dark brown. The size and shape of light patches on elytra are extremely variable: occasionally the patches are missing and elytra are all seamlessly dark brown. The bulged middle part of the pronotal base is normally straight but in some cases it is slightly curved.

Differential diagnosis.
M. alicantina
sp. nov. and
M. grandis
have long, erect setae on the elytra and pronotum while
M. leseigneuri
,
M. purkynei
and
M. variegata
possess recumbent setae.
M. alicantina
sp. nov. has denser punctation of the pronotum than
M. grandis .
The base of the pronotum of
M. alicantina
sp. nov. in the middle part is distinctly bulged and strongly extend beyond the posterior corners, and the transition to the middle bulged part is distinct and sudden, whereas in
M. grandis
it is nearly straight or only in the middle part slightly extending beyond the posterior corners of the pronotum. If the middle part is slightly bulged, transition to the bulged part is slight. The two species can be separated on the basis of the length of the aedeagal median lobe ( Figs 8, 9 ). Differences between
M. alicantina
sp. nov. and
M. grandis
are summarized in Table 1 .

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Differential diagnosis between
M. alicantina
sp. nov. and
M. grandis Peyerimhoff, 1917
.

bibRefCitation.author: Peyerimhoff, P.
bibRefCitation.refString: Peyerimhoff, P. (1917) Nouveaux Coleopteres du Nord Africain. (Vingt sixieme note: Faune du Cedre et du Sapin de Numidie). Bulletin de la Societe entomologique de France, 18, 329 - 332.

tr.td: median lobe extends to 4/5 of aedeagus in the direction from the apex to the base (Fig. 8)
median lobe extends to 3/5 of aedeagus in the direction from the apex to the base (Fig. 9)
in the middle part distinctly bulged and strongly extend beyond posterior corners; transition to the middle bulged part is distinct and sudden (Fig. 10)
nearly straight or only in the middle part slightly extend beyond posterior corners; if the middle part is slightly bulged, transition to the bulged part is mild (Fig. 11)

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. This species is named after the province Alicante, where it was found.
Bionomy. Unknown. It is plausible that this species possesses biology similar to the other species of the genus.

Collecting circumstances. All specimens were caught by window traps placed on
Quercus rotundifolia
( Figs. 14 , 15 ).
Distribution. Spain : Alicante province: Parc Natural Carrascar de la Font Roja (present study).
